Award.AwardTitle: Multiphase Models for CO2 Cleanup: Heat and Mass Transfer in Fluid-Particle Suspensions through Direct Numerical Simulation and Laser-Based Measurements

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1034307
Subramanian

Predictive models for heat and mass transfer in multiphase flows are needed for implementing carbon-neutral energy-generation technologies such as chemical looping combustion with coal or biomass, and CO2 capture from the flue gas of power plants. Recent direct numerical simulations (DNS) of flow past fixed particle assemblies suggest that heat and mass transfer models currently in use do not accurately capture relevant phenomena. To address this shortcoming, this research will investigate heat and mass transfer in fluid-particle suspensions using a combination of DNS and laser measurements of velocity and scalar fields, resulting in improved models for fluid-particle suspension flows. The improved and validated models for heat transfer can then be used by industry to evaluate and optimize fluidized bed design for CO2 capture.

Intellectual Merit: Current models for heat and mass transfer in two-fluid CFD models have not been fully validated. Specifically, unknown terms in the transport equations have not been quantified. This research addresses this need by quantifying these unknown terms using laser measurements and DNS. This new understanding will lead to improved models and simulation methodologies for interphase heat and mass transfer in fluid-particle suspensions. The validity of these models will be verified in a riser flow configuration.

Broader Impacts: Improvements to heat and mass transfer models will result in more accurate simulation of fluidized beds for chemical looping combustion and CO2 capture using dry sorbents. This will enable engineers to rapidly evaluate the viability of proposed designs. The project will leverage various institutional outreach programs to increase participation of students including those from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flow of solid particles in a gas stream is a type of multiphase flow that is encountered in energy generation processes using fossil or bio-based fuels, and emerging technologies to capture the carbon dioxide emissions. Technologies such as chemical looping combustion offer the promise of carbon-neutral energy generation. Similarly, continuous capture of carbon dioxide by dry sorbents promises to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Both these technologies can be implemented in a fluidized bed where gas is introduced into a bed of particles. Accurate prediction of the temperature field in the fluid phase is very important for many energy applications because the reaction rates in combustion chemistry are highly temperature dependent. Heat transfer between gas and solid particles is also important in the carbon dioxide capture process for efficient operation of the fluidized bed.

Computer simulations are a cost-effective approach for rapid evaluation of different process and equipment designs. Although computer simulations are increasingly used to evaluate the design of process equipment involving fluidized beds, the simulation of large industrial scale devices requires approximate representation of the details of heat and mass transfer between solid particles and gas in the form of models. A combination of experiments with detailed numerical simulation of heat and mass transfer in gas-solid flow is a promising approach to improving multiphase flow models.

In this project we performed detailed numerical simulations that resulted in fundamental understanding of the physics underlying heat and mass transfer in gas-solid flows. We compared these computational results with experimental measurements and found excellent match of the flow velocity past particles. The detailed numerical simulation results were used to develop better models for heat and mass transfer between particles and gas. The results from these simulations were reported in several national and international conferences and published in peer-reviewed journals. The computer codes developed as part of the project have been made available for public use through the GitHub repository. The models developed in this project can now be implemented in device-scale simulation codes, and this work is ongoing. We also organized an outreach activity through Iowa State University’s Office of Pre-collegiate Programs for the Talented and Gifted “Investigations” series where middle school students participated in a Granular Easter Egg Hunt STEM activity in 2015.
